newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan dollar ends softer on Fed rate hike.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan dollar ends softer on Fed rate hike.

text.p: The Taiwan dollar finished softer on Wednesday in the wake of the U.S. Federal Reserve's quarter-point overnight interest rate increase, but persistent foreign funds inflows muted the downtrend, dealers said.
The local unit finished at T$27.570, back from an intra-day low of T$27.588, against Tuesday's T$27.565 close.
Turnover through dealers was an active US$207 million.
Inflows of foreign equity funds for the stock market slowed the Taiwan dollar's fall, dealers said.

In a widely anticipated move, the U.S. central bank raised the key federal funds rate by a quarter percentage point to 5.50 percent -- the first increase since Feb. 1, 1995 -- in an effort to stay a step ahead of inflation. The federal funds rate is the rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans.
"Today's reaction was moderate because the market already had anticipated the Fed's rate hikes," said one dealer at a foreign bank.
"Many people expect the Fed to further raise the rates in the near term," the dealer said.

In addition to the U.S. dollar's general strength overseas, dealers said a slowing domestic economy, dampened by an outbreak of the deadly hog foot-and-mouth disease, would pull the Taiwan dollar further lower.

Economists and officials have predicted the farm epidemic and a resulting ban on pork exports could shave half a percentage point from Taiwan's 1997 economic growth rate, pulling it back below 6.0 percent to erase a hard-won fourth quarter acceleration.
Dealers said they expected a range of T$27.55-60 for the Taiwan dollar on Thursday. -- Alice Hung (2-5080815)
